awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Bioinspired Catalysts with Earth-Abundant Metals for Reductive Treatment of Waterborne Contaminants
awd_abstract_narration:
A collaborative team of researchers will develop a novel class of catalysts inspired by nature. These “bioinspired catalysts” will be designed for the destruction of toxic waterborne oxyanion pollutants including perchlorate, nitrate, and bromate. Oxyanions are detected worldwide in surface water, groundwater, tapwater, and wastewater. These compounds represent a substantial risk to water supplies because they are highly mobile and toxic at low concentrations. Conventional oxyanion removal technologies include selective ion exchange, reverse osmosis, and biological reduction. However, these approaches face numerous drawbacks including the disposal of secondary waste and low treatment efficiency. The catalysts will use common molybdenum (Mo) and tungsten (W) metals and novel carbon and silica-based support materials in their construction. These wil result in significantly improved reactivity and stability compared to the currently used catalysts. Successful development of effective and inexpensive catalysts will decrease the associated economic and social burdens of removing oxyanions from water. These catalysts also hold promise in the development of a new generation of bioinspired Mo/W-based materials for environmental and energy-related fields. Additional benefits include the training and development of graduate, undergraduate, and high school students through participatory research opportunities, thus improving the Nation’s science and technology workforce.

This goal of this research is to develop a novel class of Mo- and W-based bioinspired catalysts for water and wastewater treatment. The specific research objectives are to: (i) introduce Mo and W precursors into rationally designed support materials to achieve high reactivity for the removal of recalcitrant oxyanion pollutants; (ii) investigate reaction mechanisms through detailed material characterization, kinetic studies in variable water matrices, and reaction modeling and validation; and (iii) build engineered flow-through reactors to further evaluate the performance of the new catalysts for practical applications. The bioinspired catalysts use the same metal catalytic elements found in biological enzymes together with electrons from hydrogen gas to carry out the reduction of oxyanions under ambient conditions. Successful completion of this research will generate new knowledge for the development of catalytic reactors that can accommodate novel catalysts for a variety of water and wastewater treatment scenarios. This holds potential to develop new research directions in designing and applying functionalized carbon and silica materials for sustainable water purification. Beyond these research outcomes, the project will support the training and development of graduate, undergraduate, and high school students in STEM fields. Their participation in this project will prepare them for careers in industry, academia, or government agencies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Contaminants and harmful microorganisms in water can be a danger to both humans and the environment. Luckily, there are methods called advanced oxidation processes (AOPs) and disinfection that can help get rid of these pollutants. Most commonly used AOPs generate radicals for oxidation, like hydroxyl radicals, and the radicals degrade contaminants very effectively. However, the performance of radicals is significantly reduced in complex water environments, e.g., with the presence of other constituents in water. Also, radicals can produce harmful byproducts. For water disinfection, the extensive use of chemical disinfectants can threaten human health and ecosystems. 

To improve the performance of AOPs and disinfection, we developed single-atom catalysts (SACs) and double-atom catalysts (DACs) to speed up the oxidation reaction. These catalysts can simulate enzymes like peroxidases and oxidize contaminants or inactivate pathogens in a non-radical pathway. The non-radical pathway can effectively remove both chemical and biological contaminants in complex water matrices even with a low-dosage of oxidants, and they tend to produce less byproducts.

We have developed a single iron atom catalyst supported on a carbon material that has been modified with oxygen and nitrogen. This catalyst is capable of breaking down a wide range of harmful contaminants in water, known as contaminants of emerging concern (CECs), by activating substances called peroxides, specifically peroxymonosulfate (PMS). When we used the catalyst together with PMS, we found that it effectively degraded most of the selected CECs and produced powerful oxidizing agents. The catalyst also demonstrated excellent performance in degrading contaminants in complex water environments and remained stable during the oxidation process. We specifically observed that the catalyst, with an iron center coordinated with both nitrogen and oxygen atoms, showed significantly improved degradation of phenol when compared to a catalyst where iron was only coordinated with nitrogen atoms. Computer simulations suggested that FeNxO4-x had the ability to donate multiple electrons and could readily form highly reactive iron species during oxidation. Furthermore, we have also prepared a Fe-Fe double-atom catalyst, supported on a carbon material that contains sulfur and nitrogen, performs exceptionally well in the process of oxidation and activation of PMS. It activates PMS through a nonradical mechanism involving the transfer of electrons mediated by the catalyst. When applied to diverse environmental media including simulated saliva and freshwater, this Fe-Fe double-atom catalyst significantly enhances the disinfection kinetics of murine coronaviruses by 2.17 to 4.60 times compared to using PMS alone. We have also uncovered the molecular-level mechanism behind the inactivation of the murine coronavirus. The Fe-Fe double-atom catalysis not only damages the viral proteins and genomes but also disrupts a critical step in the virus's lifecycle within host cells, known as internalization. This enhances the effectiveness of PMS disinfection against the virus.

In conclusion, our single-atom Fe catalyst and double-atom Fe-Fe catalyst is highly efficient, robust, and sustainable for degrading organic contaminants and inactivating pathogens for treating water and wastewater. The work opens up new opportunities for AOPs, providing a more effective and environmentally friendly approach to removing contaminants from water sources. The work also opens up new possibilities for utilizing advanced materials to improve disinfection, sanitation, and hygiene practices, ultimately protecting public health.
